item.title: Keegan add a quote by Hugh of Saint Victor
item.description: "Therefore I beg you, reader, not to rejoice too greatly if you have read much, but if you have understood much. Nor that you have understood much, but that you have been able to retain it. Otherwise it is of little profit either to read or to understand." -- Hugh of Saint Victor

item.title: Keegan add a quote by Thomas Merton
item.description: "Despair is the absolute extreme of self-love. It is reached when a person deliberately turns his back on all help from anyone else in order to taste the rotten luxury of knowing himself to be lost" -- Thomas Merton

item.title: Keegan add a quote by David Foster Wallace
item.description: "The really important kind of freedom involves attention, and awareness, and discipline, and effort, and being able truly to care about other people and to sacrifice for them, over and over, in myriad petty little unsexy ways, every day." -- David Foster Wallace

item.title: Keegan add a quote by Sam Harris
item.description: "A kernel of truth lurks at the heart of religion, because spiritual experience, ethical behavior, and strong communities are essential for human happiness. And yet our religious traditions are intellectually defunct and politically ruinous. While spiritual experience is clearly a natural propensity of the human mind, we need not believe anything on insufficient evidence to actualize it." -- Sam Harris

item.title: Keegan add a quote by Rene Descartes
item.description: "At last I will devote myself sincerely and without reservation to the general demolition of my opinions." -- Rene Descartes

item.title: Keegan add a quote by Pema Chödrön
item.description: "Hope and fear come from feeling that we lack something; they come from a sense of poverty. We can’t simply relax with ourselves. We hold on to hope, and hope robs us of the present moment. We feel that someone else knows what is going on, but that there is something missing in us, and therefore something is lacking in our world." -- Pema Chödrön

item.title: Keegan add a quote by Henry David Thoreau
item.description: "A written word is the choicest of relics. It is something at once more intimate with us and more universal than any other work of art. It is the work of art nearest to life itself. It may be translated into every language, and not only be read but actually breathed from all human lips; -- not be represented on canvas or in marble only, but be carved out of the breath of life itself." -- Henry David Thoreau
